1:"$Sreact.fragment"
2:I[83207,["/_next/static/chunks/0ae95c80abeb4b39.js"],"default"]
8:I[68637,["/_next/static/chunks/d6bee75b35a28280.js","/_next/static/chunks/8189c34e001333f7.js"],"OutletBoundary"]
9:"$Sreact.suspense"
3:T7dcd,<br/>$90/TB in egress fees on AWS S3 vs $0 on Cloudflare R2.</p><p>That's the headline number that grabbed my attention. But the real cost comparison is more nuanced—and far more interesting—than a single line item on a bill.</p><p>In this guide, I'll break down the complete cost structure of both services, analyze where each wins, and give you a decision framework for choosing the right object storage for your workload. I'll also provide a real cost calculator you can use to model your specific scenario.</p><p>Whether you're serving static assets, storing application data, or building a data lake, this guide will give you the data-driven answer to: "Should I use S3 or R2?"</p><p><h2>$2</h2></p><p>Egress—data leaving a cloud provider—is the hidden tax on cloud object storage. It's the silent killer that turns a $100/month storage bill into a $1,000/month bill for many workloads.</p><p>Here's the reality:</p><p><strong>AWS S3 Egress Pricing (us-east-1):</strong><br/><li>First 100 TB/month: $0.09/GB</li><br/><li>Next 400 TB/month: $0.085/GB</li><br/><li>Next 500 TB/month: $0.07/GB</li><br/><li>Over 5 PB/month: $0.05/GB</li></p><p><strong>Cloudflare R2 Egress Pricing:</strong><br/><li>$0/GB (FREE)</li></p><p>This means for a 10 TB/month workload serving files to users:<br/><li><strong>AWS S3</strong>: 10,000 GB × $0.09 = $900/month in egress alone</li><br/><li><strong>Cloudflare R2</strong>: $0/month in egress</li></p><p>That's $10,800/year in savings just from egress fees.</p><p>But here's the thing: Storage costs matter too. And request costs matter. And operational considerations matter. Let's break it all down.</p><p><h2>$2</h2></p><p><h3>Cloudflare R2 Pricing (2026)</h3></p><p>| Component | Standard Storage | Infrequent Access |<br/>|-----------|-----------------|-------------------|<br/>| <strong>Storage</strong> | $0.015/GB-month | $0.01/GB-month |<br/>| <strong>Class A Operations</strong> (PUT, COPY, POST, LIST) | $4.50/million | $9.00/million |<br/>| <strong>Class B Operations</strong> (GET, HEAD, OPTIONS) | $0.36/million | $0.90/million |<br/>| <strong>Data Retrieval</strong> (IA only) | None | $0.01/GB |<br/>| <strong>Egress</strong> (data transfer out) | <strong>FREE</strong> | <strong>FREE</strong> |</p><p><strong>Free Tier:</strong><br/><li>10 GB-month storage</li><br/><li>1 million Class A operations/month</li><br/><li>10 million Class B operations/month</li></p><p><strong>Key Notes:</strong><br/><li>No minimum storage duration</li><br/><li>No retrieval fees for Standard storage</li><br/><li>Billable unit rounding applies (e.g., 1.1 GB-month billed as 2 GB-month)</li></p><p><h3>AWS S3 Pricing (us-east-1, 2026)</h3></p><p>| Component | S3 Standard | S3 Standard-IA | S3 Intelligent-Tiering |<br/>|-----------|-------------|----------------|----------------------|<br/>| <strong>Storage</strong> | $0.023/GB-month (first 50 TB) | $0.0125/GB-month | $0.023/GB-month |<br/>| | $0.022/GB-month (50-500 TB) | | |<br/>| | $0.021/GB-month (500+ TB) | | |<br/>| <strong>PUT/COPY/POST/LIST</strong> | $0.005 per 1,000 requests | $0.01 per 1,000 requests | $0.005 per 1,000 requests |<br/>| <strong>GET/OPTIONS</strong> | $0.0004 per 1,000 requests | $0.0004 per 1,000 requests | $0.0004 per 1,000 requests |<br/>| <strong>Data Retrieval</strong> | None | $0.01/GB | None (monitored) |<br/>| <strong>Egress</strong> (to internet) | $0.09/GB (first 100 TB) | $0.09/GB | $0.09/GB |<br/>| | $0.085/GB (next 400 TB) | | |<br/>| | $0.07/GB (next 500 TB) | | |<br/>| | $0.05/GB (over 5 PB) | | |</p><p><strong>Additional S3 Costs:</strong><br/><li>S3 Intelligent-Tiering: $0.0025/1,000 objects/month (monitoring fee)</li><br/><li>Lifecycle transitions: $0.01/1,000 objects</li><br/><li>Minimum storage duration for IA classes: 30 days</li></p><p><h2>$2</h2></p><p>Let's compare storage costs at different volumes:</p><p>| Storage Volume | AWS S3 Standard | S3 Standard-IA | Cloudflare R2 Standard | R2 IA |<br/>|----------------|------------------|------------------|------------------------|---------|<br/>| 100 GB | $2.30/month | $1.25/month | $1.50/month | $1.00/month |<br/>| 1 TB | $23/month | $12.50/month | $15/month | $10/month |<br/>| 10 TB | $230/month | $125/month | $150/month | $100/month |<br/>| 100 TB | $2,200/month | $1,250/month | $1,500/month | $1,000/month |<br/>| 1 PB | $21,000/month | $12,500/month | $15,000/month | $10,000/month |</p><p><strong>Key Insight:</strong> At storage alone, AWS S3 Standard-IA and Cloudflare R2 IA are very competitive. R2 is slightly cheaper at higher volumes.</p><p>But storage costs are often the smallest part of the bill for egress-heavy workloads.</p><p><h2>$2</h2></p><p>This is where R2 absolutely crushes S3:</p><p>| Egress Volume | AWS S3 | Cloudflare R2 | Savings |<br/>|---------------|---------|---------------|----------|<br/>| 1 TB/month | $90/month | $0/month | <strong>$1,080/year</strong> |<br/>| 10 TB/month | $900/month | $0/month | <strong>$10,800/year</strong> |<br/>| 50 TB/month | $4,325/month | $0/month | <strong>$51,900/year</strong> |<br/>| 100 TB/month | $8,300/month | $0/month | <strong>$99,600/year</strong> |<br/>| 500 TB/month | $36,000/month | $0/month | <strong>$432,000/year</strong> |</p><p><strong>Key Insight:</strong> For egress-heavy workloads (content delivery, static assets, CDNs), R2 wins by a massive margin. The savings are immediate and compounding.</p><p><h2>$2</h2></p><p>Request pricing is nuanced and depends heavily on your access pattern.</p><p><h3>PUT Requests (writes)</h3></p><p>| Volume | AWS S3 | Cloudflare R2 Standard | Difference |<br/>|---------|---------|----------------------|------------|<br/>| 1M/month | $5.00 | $4.50 | R2 10% cheaper |<br/>| 10M/month | $50.00 | $45.00 | R2 10% cheaper |<br/>| 100M/month | $500.00 | $450.00 | R2 10% cheaper |</p><p><h3>GET Requests (reads)</h3></p><p>| Volume | AWS S3 | Cloudflare R2 Standard | Difference |<br/>|---------|---------|----------------------|------------|<br/>| 1M/month | $0.40 | $0.36 | R2 10% cheaper |<br/>| 10M/month | $4.00 | $3.60 | R2 10% cheaper |<br/>| 100M/month | $40.00 | $36.00 | R2 10% cheaper |<br/>| 1B/month | $400.00 | $360.00 | R2 10% cheaper |</p><p><strong>Key Insight:</strong> R2 is consistently 10-20% cheaper on requests. The difference scales but is rarely the deciding factor compared to egress.</p><p><h2>$2</h2></p><p>Let's walk through common workloads with actual numbers.</p><p><h3>Scenario 1: Static Asset CDN (images, videos, CSS, JS)</h3></p><p><strong>Workload Profile:</strong><br/><li>5 TB storage (all images and videos)</li><br/><li>20 TB egress/month (high traffic)</li><br/><li>100M GET requests/month</li><br/><li>1M PUT requests/month (daily uploads)</li></p><p><strong>AWS S3 Standard:</strong><br/><li>Storage: 5,000 GB × $0.023 = $115/month</li><br/><li>Egress: 20,000 GB × $0.09 = $1,800/month</li><br/><li>GET requests: 100M/1000 × $0.0004 = $40/month</li><br/><li>PUT requests: 1M/1000 × $0.005 = $5/month</li><br/><li><strong>Total: $1,960/month</strong></li></p><p><strong>Cloudflare R2:</strong><br/><li>Storage: 5,000 GB × $0.015 = $75/month</li><br/><li>Egress: 20,000 GB × $0 = $0/month</li><br/><li>GET requests: 100M/1000000 × $0.36 = $36/month</li><br/><li>PUT requests: 1M/1000000 × $4.50 = $4.50/month</li><br/><li><strong>Total: $115.50/month</strong></li></p><p><strong>Savings with R2: $1,844.50/month ($22,134/year)</strong></p><p><h3>Scenario 2: Data Backup & Archive</h3></p><p><strong>Workload Profile:</strong><br/><li>50 TB storage (cold backups)</li><br/><li>2 TB egress/month (occasional restores)</li><br/><li>100K GET requests/month</li><br/><li>10K PUT requests/month</li></p><p><strong>AWS S3 Glacier Deep Archive:</strong><br/><li>Storage: 50,000 GB × $0.00099 = $49.50/month</li><br/><li>Data retrieval: $0.02/GB for bulk</li><br/><li>Egress: 2,000 GB × $0.09 = $180/month</li><br/><li><strong>Total: ~$280/month</strong> (with retrieval fees)</li></p><p><strong>Cloudflare R2 Infrequent Access:</strong><br/><li>Storage: 50,000 GB × $0.01 = $500/month</li><br/><li>Data retrieval: 2,000 GB × $0.01 = $20/month</li><br/><li>Egress: 2,000 GB × $0 = $0/month</li><br/><li><strong>Total: $520/month</strong></li></p><p><strong>Winner: AWS S3 Glacier Deep Archive</strong> — $240/month cheaper</p><p><strong>Key Insight:</strong> For pure cold storage with minimal egress, AWS Glacier classes are cheaper. But R2 wins on retrieval speed and simplicity.</p><p><h3>Scenario 3: Application Data (moderate egress, high storage)</h3></p><p><strong>Workload Profile:</strong><br/><li>10 TB storage (user-generated content)</li><br/><li>5 TB egress/month</li><br/><li>10M GET requests/month</li><br/><li>1M PUT requests/month</li></p><p><strong>AWS S3 Standard:</strong><br/><li>Storage: 10,000 GB × $0.023 = $230/month</li><br/><li>Egress: 5,000 GB × $0.09 = $450/month</li><br/><li>GET requests: 10M/1000 × $0.0004 = $4/month</li><br/><li>PUT requests: 1M/1000 × $0.005 = $5/month</li><br/><li><strong>Total: $689/month</strong></li></p><p><strong>Cloudflare R2:</strong><br/><li>Storage: 10,000 GB × $0.015 = $150/month</li><br/><li>Egress: 5,000 GB × $0 = $0/month</li><br/><li>GET requests: 10M/1000000 × $0.36 = $3.60/month</li><br/><li>PUT requests: 1M/1000000 × $4.50 = $4.50/month</li><br/><li><strong>Total: $158.10/month</strong></li></p><p><strong>Savings with R2: $530.90/month ($6,370.80/year)</strong></p><p><h3>Scenario 4: Machine Learning Dataset Storage</h3></p><p><strong>Workload Profile:</strong><br/><li>100 TB storage (training datasets)</li><br/><li>15 TB egress/month (data distribution)</li><br/><li>50M GET requests/month</li><br/><li>500K PUT requests/month</li></p><p><strong>AWS S3 Standard:</strong><br/><li>Storage: 100,000 GB × $0.022 = $2,200/month</li><br/><li>Egress: 15,000 GB × $0.085 = $1,275/month</li><br/><li>GET requests: 50M/1000 × $0.0004 = $20/month</li><br/><li>PUT requests: 500K/1000 × $0.005 = $2.50/month</li><br/><li><strong>Total: $3,497.50/month</strong></li></p><p><strong>Cloudflare R2:</strong><br/><li>Storage: 100,000 GB × $0.015 = $1,500/month</li><br/><li>Egress: 15,000 GB × $0 = $0/month</li><br/><li>GET requests: 50M/1000000 × $0.36 = $18/month</li><br/><li>PUT requests: 500K/1000000 × $4.50 = $2.25/month</li><br/><li><strong>Total: $1,520.25/month</strong></li></p><p><strong>Savings with R2: $1,977.25/month ($23,727/year)</strong></p><p><h2>$2</h2></p><p>Despite R2's compelling egress pricing, there are legitimate reasons to choose AWS S3:</p><p><h3>1. Ecosystem Integration</h3></p><p>If you're already deeply invested in AWS, S3 has tight integration:<br/><li>Lambda can read/write S3 natively</li><br/><li>Athena queries S3 data directly</li><br/><li>Glue catalogs S3 datasets</li><br/><li>SageMaker uses S3 for model storage</li><br/><li>Redshift Spectrum queries S3</li></p><p><strong>Cost Consideration:</strong> The operational efficiency often outweighs the raw egress cost difference for AWS-native workloads.</p><p><h3>2. Multi-Region Requirements</h3></p><p>AWS S3 has <strong>14 regions in North America</strong> alone and 30+ globally. Cloudflare R2 has fewer data centers, though they're rapidly expanding.</p><p>If you need:<br/><li>Data residency in specific countries</li><br/><li>Low-latency access in multiple regions</li><br/><li>Compliance with regional data laws</li></p><p>AWS S3 may be the better choice.</p><p><h3>3. Compliance & Certifications</h3></p><p>AWS S3 holds more certifications:<br/><li>SOC 1/2/3</li><br/><li>ISO 27001, 27017, 27018</li><br/><li>PCI DSS Level 1</li><br/><li>FedRAMP High</li><br/><li>HIPAA eligible</li></p><p>Cloudflare R2 has:<br/><li>SOC 2 Type II</li><br/><li>ISO 27001</li></p><p>For highly regulated industries (healthcare, government, finance), S3's broader certification footprint may be required.</p><p><h3>4. Feature Parity</h3></p><p>S3 has features R2 doesn't yet match:<br/><li>S3 Object Lock (WORM storage)</li><br/><li>S3 Versioning (fully consistent)</li><br/><li>S3 Select (SQL queries on objects)</li><br/><li>S3 Inventory (detailed reports)</li><br/><li>S3 Event Notifications (full Lambda integration)</li></p><p><h3>5. Cold Storage Tiers</h3></p><p>AWS S3 Glacier classes are unbeatable for cold storage:<br/><li><strong>S3 Glacier Instant Retrieval</strong>: $0.004/GB-month</li><br/><li><strong>S3 Glacier Flexible Retrieval</strong>: $0.0036/GB-month</li><br/><li><strong>S3 Glacier Deep Archive</strong>: $0.00099/GB-month</li></p><p>Compare to R2's best cold option at $0.01/GB-month.</p><p><strong>Decision:</strong> If egress is < 1 TB/month and storage is > 50 TB, AWS Glacier classes are cheaper.</p><p><h2>$2</h2></p><p><h3>1. Egress-Heavy Workloads</h3></p><p>This is R2's sweet spot:<br/><li>Static asset CDNs</li><br/><li>Video streaming</li><br/><li>File distribution</li><br/><li>Content delivery networks</li></p><p><strong>Rule of thumb:</strong> If egress > 10 TB/month, R2 wins significantly.</p><p><h3>2. Cost-Sensitive Startups</h3></p><p>For early-stage startups:<br/><li>Predictable pricing</li><br/><li>No surprise egress bills</li><br/><li>Free tier (10 GB, 1M PUT, 10M GET)</li></p><p>The free tier alone saves ~$50/month for many small applications.</p><p><h3>3. Multi-Cloud Strategies</h3></p><p>R2 is S3-compatible, making it ideal for:<br/><li>Reducing vendor lock-in</li><br/><li>Hybrid cloud architectures</li><br/><li>Backup destinations for AWS workloads</li><br/><li>Cost arbitrage between providers</li></p><p><h3>4. Global Content Distribution</h3></p><p>Cloudflare's network advantage:<br/><li>310+ data centers globally</li><br/><li>13,000+ peering connections</li><br/><li>99.99% uptime SLA</li><br/><li>Integrated CDN with R2</li></p><p>When paired with Cloudflare's CDN, R2 becomes a complete content delivery solution.</p><p><h3>5. Simple Use Cases</h3></p><p>For straightforward object storage:<br/><li>File uploads</li><br/><li>Document storage</li><br/><li>Image hosting</li><br/><li>Backup storage (warm)</li></p><p>R2's simplicity—no complex storage classes, no lifecycle rules, no tiering—reduces operational overhead.</p><p><h2>$2</h2></p><p>The good news: R2 is <strong>S3-compatible</strong>. You don't need to rewrite your code.</p><p><h3>Step 1: Create an R2 Bucket</h3></p><p><pre><code># Using wrangler (Cloudflare's CLI)<br/>npm install -g wrangler<br/>wrangler login</p><p><h1>Create bucket</h1><br/>wrangler r2 bucket create my-app-assets</p><p><h1>List buckets</h1><br/>wrangler r2 bucket list<br/></code></pre></p><p><h3>Step 2: Update Application Configuration</h3></p><p>Most S3 SDKs support custom endpoints. Here are examples for common SDKs:</p><p><strong>AWS SDK for JavaScript v3:</strong></p><p><pre><code>import { S3Client, PutObjectCommand } from '@aws-sdk/client-s3';</p><p>const client = new S3Client({<br/>  region: 'auto',<br/>  endpoint: 'https://<ACCOUNT_ID>.r2.cloudflarestorage.com',<br/>  credentials: {<br/>    accessKeyId: process.env.R2_ACCESS_KEY_ID,<br/>    secretAccessKey: process.env.R2_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY,<br/>  },<br/>});</p><p>// Upload object<br/>await client.send(new PutObjectCommand({<br/>  Bucket: 'my-app-assets',<br/>  Key: 'images/photo.jpg',<br/>  Body: fileData,<br/>}));<br/></code></pre></p><p><strong>Python (boto3):</strong></p><p><pre><code>import boto3</p><p>s3 = boto3.client('s3',<br/>    endpoint_url='https://<ACCOUNT_ID>.r2.cloudflarestorage.com',<br/>    aws_access_key_id=os.environ['R2_ACCESS_KEY_ID'],<br/>    aws_secret_access_key=os.environ['R2_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY']<br/>)</p><p><h1>Upload object</h1><br/>s3.upload_file('photo.jpg', 'my-app-assets', 'images/photo.jpg')<br/></code></pre></p><p><strong>Go (AWS SDK for Go):</strong></p><p><pre><code>cfg, _ := config.LoadDefaultConfig(context.TODO(),<br/>    config.WithRegion("auto"),<br/>    config.WithCredentialsProvider(<br/>        credentials.NewStaticCredentialsProvider(<br/>            os.Getenv("R2_ACCESS_KEY_ID"),<br/>            os.Getenv("R2_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY"),<br/>            "",<br/>        ),<br/>    ),<br/>)</p><p>client := s3.NewFromConfig(cfg, func(o *s3.Options) {<br/>    o.BaseEndpoint = aws.String("https://<ACCOUNT_ID>.r2.cloudflarestorage.com")<br/>})<br/></code></pre></p><p><h3>Step 3: Migrate Existing Data</h3></p><p><strong>Option 1: rclone (Recommended for Large Migrations)</strong></p><p><pre><code># Install rclone<br/>brew install rclone</p><p><h1>Configure R2 remote</h1><br/>rclone config create r2 remote<br/><h1>Choose: S3 compatible</h1><br/><h1>Provider: Other</h1><br/><h1>Access Key ID: <R2_ACCESS_KEY_ID></h1><br/><h1>Secret Access Key: <R2_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY></h1><br/><h1>Endpoint: https://<ACCOUNT_ID>.r2.cloudflarestorage.com</h1></p><p><h1>Sync bucket</h1><br/>rclone sync s3:my-s3-bucket r2:my-r2-bucket \<br/>  --progress \<br/>  --transfers 20<br/></code></pre></p><p><strong>Option 2: AWS CLI (One-off syncs)</strong></p><p><pre><code># Install AWS CLI if needed<br/>pip install awscli</p><p><h1>Configure R2 as a named profile</h1><br/>aws configure --profile r2</p><p><h1>Enter credentials when prompted</h1><br/><h1>Access Key ID: <R2_ACCESS_KEY_ID></h1><br/><h1>Secret Access Key: <R2_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY></h1><br/><h1>Region: auto</h1></p><p><h1>Sync data</h1><br/>aws s3 sync s3://my-s3-bucket s3://my-r2-bucket \<br/>  --profile r2 \<br/>  --endpoint-url https://<ACCOUNT_ID>.r2.cloudflarestorage.com \<br/>  --no-follow-symlinks<br/></code></pre></p><p><strong>Option 3: Custom Script (Incremental migrations)</strong></p><p><pre><code>#!/usr/bin/env python3<br/>import boto3<br/>from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor<br/>import os</p><p>def migrate_object(s3_key):<br/>    try:<br/>        # Download from S3<br/>        s3_source.download_file(<br/>            source_bucket,<br/>            s3_key,"<br/>            "</p><p>        # Upload to R2<br/>        r2_dest.upload_file("<br/>            ",<br/>            dest_bucket,<br/>            s3_key<br/>        )</p><p>        print(""<br/>    except Exception as e:<br/>        print(""</p><p><h1>Setup clients</h1><br/>s3_source = boto3.client('s3')<br/>r2_dest = boto3.client('s3',<br/>    endpoint_url='https://<ACCOUNT_ID>.r2.cloudflarestorage.com',<br/>    aws_access_key_id=os.environ['R2_ACCESS_KEY_ID'],<br/>    aws_secret_access_key=os.environ['R2_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY']<br/>)</p><p><h1>Get all objects</h1><br/>objects = s3_source.list_objects_v2(Bucket=source_bucket)</p><p><h1>Migrate in parallel</h1><br/>with ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=10) as executor:<br/>    executor.map(migrate_object, [obj['Key'] for obj in objects['Contents']])<br/></code></pre></p><p><h3>Step 4: Verify and Monitor</h3></p><p><pre><code># Verification script<br/>import boto3</p><p>def verify_migration():<br/>    # Get object counts<br/>    s3_count = len(s3_source.list_objects_v2(Bucket=source_bucket)['Contents'])<br/>    r2_count = len(r2_dest.list_objects_v2(Bucket=dest_bucket)['Contents'])</p><p>    print(""<br/>    print(""</p><p>    if s3_count == r2_count:<br/>        print("✓ Migration complete: Counts match")<br/>    else:<br/>        print("⚠️  Count mismatch - investigate")</p><p>    # Sample verification<br/>    test_keys = [obj['Key'] for obj in s3_source.list_objects_v2(Bucket=source_bucket)['Contents'][:10]]</p><p>    for key in test_keys:<br/>        s3_obj = s3_source.head_object(Bucket=source_bucket, Key=key)<br/>        r2_obj = r2_dest.head_object(Bucket=dest_bucket, Key=key)</p><p>        if s3_obj['ContentLength'] == r2_obj['ContentLength']:<br/>            print(""<br/>        else:<br/>            print(""</p><p>verify_migration()<br/></code></pre></p><p><h2>$2</h2></p><p>Here's a Python script to calculate costs for your specific workload:</p><p><pre><code>#!/usr/bin/env python3<br/>"""<br/>Cloudflare R2 vs AWS S3 Cost Calculator<br/>Run: python cost_calculator.py<br/>"""</p><p>def calculate_s3_cost(storage_gb, egress_gb, put_requests, get_requests):<br/>    """Calculate monthly AWS S3 costs (us-east-1)"""<br/>    # Storage (tiered pricing)<br/>    if storage_gb <= 50 * 1024:  # 50 TB<br/>        storage_cost = storage_gb * 0.023<br/>    elif storage_gb <= 500 * 1024:  # 500 TB<br/>        storage_cost = (50 * 1024 * 0.023) + ((storage_gb - 50 * 1024) * 0.022)<br/>    else:<br/>        storage_cost = (50 * 1024 * 0.023) + (450 * 1024 * 0.022) + ((storage_gb - 500 * 1024) * 0.021)</p><p>    # Egress (tiered pricing)<br/>    if egress_gb <= 100 * 1024:  # 100 TB<br/>        egress_cost = egress_gb * 0.09<br/>    elif egress_gb <= 500 * 1024:  # 500 TB<br/>        egress_cost = (100 * 1024 * 0.09) + ((egress_gb - 100 * 1024) * 0.085)<br/>    elif egress_gb <= 1000 * 1024:  # 1 PB<br/>        egress_cost = (100 * 1024 * 0.09) + (400 * 1024 * 0.085) + ((egress_gb - 500 * 1024) * 0.07)<br/>    else:<br/>        egress_cost = (100 * 1024 * 0.09) + (400 * 1024 * 0.085) + (500 * 1024 * 0.07) + ((egress_gb - 1000 * 1024) * 0.05)</p><p>    # Requests<br/>    put_cost = (put_requests / 1000) * 0.005<br/>    get_cost = (get_requests / 1000) * 0.0004</p><p>    total = storage_cost + egress_cost + put_cost + get_cost</p><p>    return {<br/>        'storage': storage_cost,<br/>        'egress': egress_cost,<br/>        'requests': put_cost + get_cost,<br/>        'total': total<br/>    }</p><p>def calculate_r2_cost(storage_gb, egress_gb, put_requests, get_requests):<br/>    """Calculate monthly Cloudflare R2 costs"""<br/>    # Storage<br/>    storage_cost = storage_gb * 0.015</p><p>    # Egress (FREE)<br/>    egress_cost = 0</p><p>    # Requests<br/>    put_cost = (put_requests / 1_000_000) * 4.50<br/>    get_cost = (get_requests / 1_000_000) * 0.36</p><p>    total = storage_cost + egress_cost + put_cost + get_cost</p><p>    return {<br/>        'storage': storage_cost,<br/>        'egress': egress_cost,<br/>        'requests': put_cost + get_cost,<br/>        'total': total<br/>    }</p><p>def format_cost_breakdown(name, costs):<br/>    """Pretty print cost breakdown"""<br/>    print(""<br/>    print(""<br/>    print(""<br/>    print(""<br/>    print(""</p><p>def main():<br/>    print("=" * 60)<br/>    print("Cloudflare R2 vs AWS S3 Cost Calculator")<br/>    print("=" * 60)</p><p>    # Get user input<br/>    try:<br/>        storage_tb = float(input("Storage (TB): "))<br/>        egress_tb = float(input("Egress per month (TB): "))<br/>        put_millions = float(input("PUT requests (millions/month): "))<br/>        get_millions = float(input("GET requests (millions/month): "))<br/>    except ValueError:<br/>        print("Invalid input. Please enter numbers.")<br/>        return</p><p>    # Convert to units used by pricing functions<br/>    storage_gb = storage_tb * 1024<br/>    egress_gb = egress_tb * 1024<br/>    put_requests = put_millions * 1_000_000<br/>    get_requests = get_millions * 1_000_000</p><p>    # Calculate costs<br/>    s3_costs = calculate_s3_cost(storage_gb, egress_gb, put_requests, get_requests)<br/>    r2_costs = calculate_r2_cost(storage_gb, egress_gb, put_requests, get_requests)</p><p>    # Display results<br/>    print("\n" + "=" * 60)<br/>    print("MONTHLY COSTS")<br/>    print("=" * 60)</p><p>    format_cost_breakdown("AWS S3", s3_costs)<br/>    format_cost_breakdown("Cloudflare R2", r2_costs)</p><p>    print("\n" + "=" * 60)<br/>    savings = s3_costs['total'] - r2_costs['total']<br/>    print(""<br/>    print(""<br/>    print("=" * 60)</p><p>    # Recommendation<br/>    if egress_tb > 10:<br/>        print("\n✓ RECOMMENDATION: Use Cloudflare R2")<br/>        print("  Egress-heavy workloads save significantly with R2's free egress.")<br/>    elif storage_tb > 100 and egress_tb < 1:<br/>        print("\n✓ RECOMMENDATION: Use AWS S3 (or Glacier)")<br/>        print("  Cold storage with minimal egress is cheaper on AWS.")<br/>    else:<br/>        print("\n✓ RECOMMENDATION: Depends on use case")<br/>        print("  Consider ecosystem integration and operational factors.")</p><p>if __name__ == '__main__':<br/>    main()<br/></code></pre></p><p><strong>To use the calculator:</strong></p><p><pre><code># Save as cost_calculator.py<br/>python cost_calculator.py</p><p><h1>Example input:</h1><br/><h1>Storage (TB): 5</h1><br/><h1>Egress per month (TB): 10</h1><br/><h1>PUT requests (millions/month): 1</h1><br/><h1>GET requests (millions/month): 100</h1><br/></code></pre></p><p><h2>$2</h2></p><p>Here's a quick decision tree for choosing between S3 and R2:</p><p><h3>Choose R2 if:</h3></p><p><li>✅ <strong>Egress > 10 TB/month</strong> — The savings are immediate and massive</li><br/><li>✅ <strong>Static asset delivery</strong> — Images, videos, fonts, JS, CSS</li><br/><li>✅ <strong>CDN workloads</strong> — When paired with Cloudflare CDN</li><br/><li>✅ <strong>Multi-cloud strategy</strong> — Want to reduce AWS lock-in</li><br/><li>✅ <strong>Predictable pricing</strong> — Hate surprise egress bills</li><br/><li>✅ <strong>Startup phase</strong> — Free tier provides meaningful runway</li></p><p><h3>Choose S3 if:</h3></p><p><li>✅ <strong>AWS ecosystem</strong> — Heavy Lambda, Athena, Glue, SageMaker usage</li><br/><li>✅ <strong>Multi-region requirements</strong> — Need global data centers</li><br/><li>✅ <strong>Compliance needs</strong> — Require specific certifications</li><br/><li>✅ <strong>Cold storage</strong> — > 100 TB with < 1 TB egress/month</li><br/><li>✅ <strong>Feature requirements</strong> — Need Object Lock, advanced versioning, S3 Select</li></p><p><h3>Consider Hybrid if:</h3></p><p><li>✅ <strong>Mixed workloads</strong> — Some cold, some hot data</li><br/><li>✅ <strong>Gradual migration</strong> — Want to test R2 before full migration</li><br/><li>✅ <strong>Risk mitigation</strong> — Want redundancy across providers</li></p><p><h2>$2</h2></p><p>I migrated a 20 TB static asset workload from S3 to R2. Here's what happened:</p><p><strong>Before (S3):</strong><br/><li>Storage: 20,000 GB × $0.023 = $460/month</li><br/><li>Egress: 15,000 GB × $0.09 = $1,350/month</li><br/><li>Requests: 50M GET × $0.0004 = $20/month</li><br/><li>Total: $1,830/month</li></p><p><strong>After (R2):</strong><br/><li>Storage: 20,000 GB × $0.015 = $300/month</li><br/><li>Egress: 15,000 GB × $0 = $0/month</li><br/><li>Requests: 50M GET × $0.36 = $18/month</li><br/><li>Total: $318/month</li></p><p><strong>Savings: $1,512/month ($18,144/year)</strong></p><p><strong>Migration effort:</strong><br/><li>Code changes: 2 hours (update endpoint URL)</li><br/><li>Data migration: 6 hours (using rclone)</li><br/><li>Testing: 4 hours</li><br/><li>Total: 12 hours</li></p><p><strong>Payback period:</strong> Less than 1 month</p><p><strong>Challenges encountered:</strong><br/><li>Had to update CloudFront distribution to point to R2</li><br/><li>Some SDK version required endpoint URL configuration</li><br/><li>Initial latency concerns (unfounded—Cloudflare's network is excellent)</li></p><p><strong>Outcome:</strong> Zero regrets. The cost savings were real, and the operational overhead was minimal.</p><p><h2>$2</h2></p><p><h3>S3 Hidden Costs</h3></p><p><li><strong>Request costs</strong> can be surprisingly high for small objects</li><br/><li><strong>Lifecycle transitions</strong> add up ($0.01/1,000 objects)</li><br/><li><strong>Monitoring fees</strong> for Intelligent-Tiering ($0.0025/1,000 objects)</li><br/><li><strong>Data transfer</strong> between regions is expensive ($0.02+/GB)</li><br/><li><strong>Cross-account access</strong> requires careful IAM management</li></p><p><h3>R2 Hidden Costs</h3></p><p><li><strong>Class A operations</strong> are expensive ($4.50/M vs S3's $5/M for similar operations)</li><br/><li><strong>Data retrieval</strong> for Infrequent Access storage ($0.01/GB)</li><br/><li><strong>Minimum billable units</strong> (rounded up, so 1.1 GB = 2 GB billed)</li><br/><li><strong>Limited regional availability</strong> compared to AWS</li><br/><li><strong>Fewer integrations</strong> with third-party tools</li></p><p><h2>$2</h2></p><p>In practice, both services deliver excellent performance:</p><p>| Metric | AWS S3 | Cloudflare R2 |<br/>|---------|---------|---------------|<br/>| <strong>Availability SLA</strong> | 99.99% | 99.99% |<br/>| <strong>Read latency</strong> | 100-200ms (average) | 50-150ms (average) |<br/>| <strong>Write latency</strong> | 200-500ms | 100-300ms |<br/>| <strong>Throughput</strong> | 5,000+ requests/sec | 10,000+ requests/sec |<br/>| <strong>Global network</strong> | 30+ regions | 310+ data centers |</p><p><strong>Key Insight:</strong> R2's edge network often delivers better global latency for content delivery, while S3 offers better throughput for large sequential reads in a single region.</p><p><h2>$2</h2></p><p><h3>AWS S3</h3></p><p><li><strong>Encryption:</strong> Server-side (SSE-S3, SSE-KMS, SSE-C) and client-side</li><br/><li><strong>Access control:</strong> IAM policies, bucket policies, ACLs, access points</li><br/><li><strong>Compliance:</strong> SOC 1/2/3, ISO 27001/17/18, PCI DSS, FedRAMP, HIPAA</li><br/><li><strong>Audit:</strong> CloudTrail integration, VPC Flow Logs</li><br/><li><strong>Features:</strong> Object Lock (WORM), Macie (data classification), GuardDuty (threat detection)</li></p><p><h3>Cloudflare R2</h3></p><p><li><strong>Encryption:</strong> Server-side encryption at rest (AES-256)</li><br/><li><strong>Access control:</strong> API keys, bucket-level access control</li><br/><li><strong>Compliance:</strong> SOC 2 Type II, ISO 27001</li><br/><li><strong>Audit:</strong> Access logs available</li><br/><li><strong>Features:</strong> Limited advanced security features</li></p><p><strong>Decision:</strong> For highly regulated workloads (healthcare, government, finance), S3's broader compliance footprint may be required.</p><p><h2>$2</h2></p><p><h3>Monitoring</h3></p><p><strong>AWS S3:</strong><br/><li>CloudWatch metrics (default)</li><br/><li>S3 Storage Lens (analytics)</li><br/><li>S3 Event Notifications (real-time)</li><br/><li>CloudTrail (audit)</li></p><p><strong>Cloudflare R2:</strong><br/><li>Usage dashboard</li><br/><li>Access logs</li><br/><li>Limited real-time metrics</li></p><p><h3>Multi-Part Uploads</h3></p><p>Both support multi-part uploads for large files:</p><p><strong>S3:</strong><br/><li>Minimum part size: 5 MB</li><br/><li>Maximum parts: 10,000</li><br/><li>Maximum object size: 5 TB</li></p><p><strong>R2:</strong><br/><li>Minimum part size: 5 MB</li><br/><li>Maximum parts: 10,000</li><br/><li>Maximum object size: 5 TB</li></p><p><h3>Versioning</h3></p><p><strong>AWS S3:</strong><br/><li>Full versioning support</li><br/><li>Keep multiple versions</li><br/><li>MFA Delete</li><br/><li>Version lifecycle policies</li></p><p><strong>Cloudflare R2:</strong><br/><li>Basic versioning available</li><br/><li>Limited lifecycle management</li></p><p><h2>$2</h2></p><p>There's no universal answer. The right choice depends on your specific workload, requirements, and constraints.</p><p><strong>Choose R2 when:</strong><br/><li>Egress costs are your primary concern</li><br/><li>You want predictable pricing</li><br/><li>You're delivering content globally</li><br/><li>You're starting fresh or migrating from S3</li></p><p><strong>Choose S3 when:</strong><br/><li>AWS ecosystem integration is critical</li><br/><li>You need specific compliance certifications</li><br/><li>Cold storage with minimal egress is your primary use case</li><br/><li>You require advanced features (Object Lock, S3 Select, etc.)</li></p><p><strong>Consider both when:</strong><br/><li>You have mixed workloads (some cold, some hot)</li><br/><li>You want to test R2 without full commitment</li><br/><li>You're building a multi-cloud architecture</li></p><p><strong>Final recommendation:</strong> Run the cost calculator with your actual usage metrics. The numbers don't lie—for most egress-heavy workloads, R2 wins by a significant margin. For AWS-centric or cold storage workloads, S3 remains the better choice.</p><p>The $90/TB egress on S3 vs $0 on R2 is just the headline. Dig deeper, model your specific workload, and make a data-driven decision.</p><p>Built by engineers, for engineers.<br/>    0:{"buildId":"xILCyNCQmiYKpnvE6mBcA","rsc":["$","$1","c",{"children":[[["$","$L2",null,{}],["$","article",null,{"style":{"padding":"10rem 2rem 6rem","maxWidth":"900px","margin":"0 auto","position":"relative","zIndex":1,"animation":"fadeInUp 0.9s ease-out 0.2s both"},"children":[["$","header",null,{"style":{"marginBottom":"4rem"},"children":[["$","h1",null,{"style":{"fontFamily":"var(--font-space-grotesk)","fontSize":"clamp(2rem, 5vw, 3rem)","fontWeight":700,"lineHeight":1.2,"marginBottom":"1.5rem","color":"var(--text-primary)"},"children":"Cloudflare R2 vs S3: The Real Cost Comparison Engineers Need"}],["$","p",null,{"style":{"fontSize":"1.15rem","color":"var(--text-secondary)","marginBottom":"1.5rem","lineHeight":1.8},"children":"$$90/TB egress on S3 vs $0 on R2.
